reviewText: The topics dealt with in the story have been already treated thousands of times : a man avenging his father, a love story between a rich "gringa" and a poor latino, cops crossing the line for the good cause, etc. Even the portrayal of Dominican Republic is not devoid of the usual clichés : rooster fights, bachata, etc. In the end, the movie is not unpleasant but kind of conventional, and does not convey any surprise

reviewText: This is a pretty good movie considering the circumstances of filming in a third world country like the Dominican Republic. I lived there for several years and go back frequently to visit the beaches and see old friends. There are many sides to this country and one of them is graphically displayed in this film: Violence. No doubt about it, the DR (as most call it) is a violent place to be. The tourists that go there by the thousands encounter a sheltered life in the high class resorts that ring the island and see little or nothing of the underbelly of this country in the sun. The movie I believe exaggerates on many levels so one's acceptance that a rogue cop could be out there murdering suspects at night and being a butcher during the day is a stretch. Anyone thinking that this sort of thing goes on nowadays is wrong. It's just fiction. That said, there is plenty wrong with the police and the system of justice operating in the DR. Corruption is rife and hoodlum cops abound. So La Soga gets it right sort of however that a cop could murder bad guys in public and on TV and get away with it challenges the imagination. OK then...the film is engrossing, the acting a bit melodramatic and amateurish, the plot hackneyed, the cinema verite/documentary aspects work well, and the conclusion (a happy one) is unexpected given the run up to the ending. I liked it over all and knowing the DR as I do made it more fun to watch. The cover jacket of the DVD compares it to recent ground breaking Latin American films. Don't believe it. It is entertaining if you like to watch people shot in the head but it's no gritty "City of God."  The camera work is good to excellent, the shot on location scenes work well, and you'll see a lot of Santiago slums if that's your thing. As I said it's a surprisingly good film given the handicaps filming in the DR. Manny Perez, the principal actor, has a good future in films of this nature. He tough and believable. La Soga translates as "The Rope," literally, but could also mean the hangman.  Buy it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Alternately brutal and tender, this is a fine movie and highly recommended.  Yes, the storyline is ancient (literally) but still powerful.  La Soga (The Rope) is Manny Perez, who also wrote and produced the movie.  This is an intense and complex role... if he seems a little one-dimensional, it somehow works anyway.  If you like this movie (and are OK with subtitles) check out the two "Mesrine" movies (France), "Elite Squad" (Brazil), "Maria Full of Grace" (Columbia), and one of cinema's greatest triumphs, "City of God" (Brazil).  All are movies you will not forget and will recommend over and over.  All may or may not be on Amazon, I don't recall.

reviewText: Rarely, if ever, do I rate a product five on content alone - but this was one of Screen Media's best efforts to date both on quality of DVD and of the film itself. Admittedly, I last saw the lead Manny Ramirez inPride and Glory [Blu-ray], but as overlooked as this film will be, he gave an amazing and powerful performance.The (supposedly based on true events) story follows a Dom. Rep. law enforcement officer as he treads the line of brutally enforcing the law while trying to accept what he has become through the years - all of which we see in development of this persona through the interpolation of flashbacks and present day events. The film making is flashy, at times maybe hard to follow, but all of it becomes so relevant as it both plays out and becomes clear as to why it is told in the fashion that it is. The performances, music score, style of production and lineage of story make this film a solid piece of entertainment - yet it holds a caliber of maintaining a semblance of professionalism to satisfy even the critical eye.Disclaimers: this movie shows both brutal realism regarding animal cruelty (chicken and pig supporters will be in an uproar) and real-life South/North American drug enforcement politicism - so if you have sensitivity towards either - skip this film as they held nothing back. Several reviews out there have lambasted this piece for a variety of reasons (and in my opinion all without merit), so please give this one a chance for such simple reasons as DVD picture quality, acting performances and realism of content.The DVD has Spanish subs only, with English built in - and that is it. Region 1 coded, but crystal clear on sound and picture. I will gladly buy your copy if you feel wronged because of my review.EDIT: Changed the location to properly represent the country (per corrections in the comments section).
summary: Brutal yet beautiful film...5 stars on film alone

reviewText: In "La Soga" (also titled "The Butcher's Son"). Manny Perez is Luisito, a cop working for the Santiago secret police. This is a story of corruption and justice reminiscent of the 70s gritty crime dramas. But if you are looking for action-filled shootouts and car chases, sorry, this is not a film for you, as "La Soga" is more like a character-driven drama with charismatic Manny Perez (who also wrote the script) as our anti-hero.Some call "La Soga" an action film or a revenge thriller, but the Dominican film focuses on the character of Luisito, a butcher's son turned into a killer hired by General Colon (Juan Fernández). What Luisito wants is the death of the murderer of his father, and he eliminates those who are on the list given by the general, waiting for the chance to revenge. But these days he is tired. And when his childhood friend Jenny (Denise Quiñones) comes back, he starts to think of quitting the job.Most supporting actors turn in effective acting (Paul Calderon as the criminal in particular) and the film benefits from the convincing locations However, "La Soga" directed by Josh Crook, suffers from clichéd settings and familiar narrative devices. Its romance is not necessary. The flashback scenes are too many. The metaphors of killing pigs are obvious and repetitious."La Soga" is a well-made crime drama, but not exactly a very original one.
summary: (3.5 STARS) Dominican Crime Drama with Charismatic Manny Perez
Title: N/A

reviewText: "La Soga" means "The Rope/Noose", which is a fitting title since this movie is about a state-sponsored extra-judicial executioner. This film is dark, gritty, & just a honest depiction of life in a slum. There were moments where I hid my eyes from the screen a bit because sometimes it became too graphic. The plot may have been somewhat predictable, but the actors were quite believable in their roles. You will notice that a lot of the drug-dealers are either of African descent or mixed race in this film. I am wondering if the clear racial bias in this movie is not just a reflection of the overt racism towards blacks in the Dominican Republic (& many other Latin countries). This racism along with the judicious violence (such as the detailed shots of dying people & animals) did not sit well with me, so it greatly diminished my enjoyment of this film.
Title: N/A
